item.title: Review of the Benefits of Vitamin D and Recommendations
Vitamin D facts from Sunlight Institute
item.description:
1. As sun exposure in the U.S. has DECREASED by 90% during the last century, melanoma incidence has INCREASED BY 3,000%.
    1. A 20-year Swedish study shows that sun avoidance is as bad for the health as cigarette smoking.
    1. A Spanish study shows that women who seek the sun have one-eleventh the hip fracture risk as those who avoid sun.
    1. Men who work outdoors have half the risk of melanoma as those who work indoors.
    1. Women who totally avoid the sun have 10-times the risk of breast cancer.
    1. Women who sunbathe regularly have half the risk of death during a 20-year period compared to those who stay indoors.
    1. Sun exposure increases nitric oxide production, which leads to a decrease in heart attack risk.
    1. Vitamin D, the sunshine vitamin, is essential to human survival, and sun exposure is the only natural way to obtain it.

   Sunbathing can produce 20,000 units of vitamin D in 20 minutes of whole-body exposure.

item.title: Taking vitamin D extends life - 56 trials with 100,000 people - Dr. Greger video
item.description:
Great general Vitamin D video (4 minutes)

Transcript and list of sources are further down on this page

Video transcript

In 1822, a Polish physician was the first to publish that sunlight could cure the vitamin D deficiency disease rickets. His work was ignored by mainstream medicine for a century, not coming into widespread use until the 20th century, when wire cages were affixed to tenement buildings so babies could benefit from the sun. Are we in a similar situation now, where the medical profession has just not caught up with the science?

What is vitamin D?

Vitamin D is one of the chemicals that the tissues of our body use to unlock the DNA blueprints needed for our cells to produce various of the products required for cell growth, signaling, differentiation, and immunity. Vitamin D is chemically related to cholesterol and to the large family of steroid hormones; it is called, in chemical terms, a “seco-steroid”.

item.title: VITAMIN D: A D-LIGHTFUL SOLUTION FOR GOOD HEALTH – Holick 2012
item.description:
J Med Biochem 31: 263-264, 2012; Editorial

Michael F. Holick Boston University School of Medicine, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Adequate vitamin D nutrition is associated with the prevention of rickets in children and therefore little thought is given to the consequences of vitamin D deficiency in adults. However, it is now becoming clear that vitamin D plays an important role in maintaining bone health from birth until death. Of equal importance is that vitamin D has a multitude of other biologic functions in the body that may be significant for the prevention of common cancers, hypertension, type 1 diabetes, as well as a host of other common maladies that afflict elders (1-4).
